title: September 5
description:
It's been a busy week! We still haven't managed to get mobile phones or a fully functioning bank account, but we did get officially matriculated with the social security administration. Just in time too: on the day our American health insurance expired, Milo broke his wrist. So far, socialized medicine has delivered: full treatment, no bills.

Thursday was "la rentrée des classes" (back-to-school). Despite a scare at first (Felix got put in the wrong grade), all went well in the end. Both Felix and Milo like their teachers and they have made a friend each. Lucie is in love with "La Cantine" (the cafeteria)… no making school lunches for a whole year!!! The kids are served a hot, balanced, sit-down meal they actually eat and enjoy.

This weekend was "Le Forum des Associations": a back-to-school ritual across France, where you go and choose after-school activities for the kids. We are leaning toward Vovinam Viet Vo Dao, a vietnamese martial art reminiscent of Cuong Nhu, the martial art practiced at the kids' dojo in Berkeley. Felix is going next week for a trial class. Stay tuned.

children.title: Gilles
children.description:
Gilles Mathiot, an old family friend that Lucie hadn't seen in 19 years, came over for supper.

Justine, Gilles, Lucie and Françoise.

children.title: Cousin Camp
children.description: Iris and Zoe stayed over at our place for three days straight. It was a cousin fest!

children.title: Dress-Up
children.description: Every toy of the house got played with. The costume box, in particular, saw lots of action.

children.title: Garden
children.description:
Our garden, viewed from Dean's office.

Baboushka and four grandchildren are heading out to the park.

children.title: Buttes Chaumont
children.description: On Wednesday, the day before school started, Dean and Baboushka took the 4 cousins to Les Buttes Chaumont, a grand romantic park in the 20th arrondissement.

children.title: Playground
children.description:
While both the park and the weather were fabulous, it was an ill-fated excursion.
  • First, Zoe got lost.
  • Then, Felix and Iris got lost looking for Zoe.
  • Then, after they had all been found, Felix managed to lock himself in the bathroom.
  • Then, after the groundskeeper rescued Felix from the bathroom, Milo had a bad fall from the play structure and broke his wrist.

children.title: Pirate Cafe
children.description:
This is Milo at the Pirate Cafe in Les Buttes Chaumont, shortly before he fell from the play structure.

After the fall he cried and complained that his wrist hurt a lot. Dean took him home by taxi; iced his wrist and calmed him down with some Club Penguin. But an hour later, the sharp pain when he moved his wrist still hadn't gone. We faced the fact that his wrist was probably broken.

We took him to the hospital where X-rays confirmed the break (a mild one, as far as these things go) and his arm was put in a cast. He'll have it for four weeks. It's on his left hand so he can still write.

We all came home exhausted and Milo didn't sleep much that night. Not the best preparation for the first day of school.

children.title: Cast
children.description: Despite his fresh cast and restless night, Milo woke up in a good mood and ready to shoulder his "cartable" (satchel) and seize the day.

children.title: Walk to School
children.description: Walking to school takes less than 5 minutes. It's that close.

children.title: Romain Rolland
children.description:
Everyone waits patiently for the doors to open at 8:30 am. The kids go in by themselves. Parents aren't allowed inside.

We are used to the more parent-inclusive style of Ecole Bilingue and are in withdrawal... we yearn to see our kids' classrooms and meet their teachers!

children.title: La Rentrée
children.description: La Rentrée Scolaire à l'école Romain Rolland.

children.title: First Day
children.description: Everyone is a little nervous on the first day of school.

children.title: Milo
children.description: Milo and his fresh cast, on his way to CP ("Cours Préparatoire", 1st grade).

children.title: Felix
children.description:
Felix was sent to the wrong grade on the first day.

The grade cutoff dates are different in France, so the school assigned him to 4th grade (the French call it CM1: Cours Moyen 1ere Année). We explained that there had been a mistake: he was in 2nd grade last year and now belongs in 3rd grade (known as CE2: Cours Elémentaire 2e année). To our bafflement, the principal categorically refused. We explained that the cutoff in the U.S. is December 1st and not December 31st. She still refused. We were stunned.

We spent the day worrying and looking for a solution. Fortunately, when we picked up Felix from school in the afternoon, he said he had been transferred to 3rd grade after lunch. Perhaps his teacher reported to the principal that Felix is clearly not yet at 4th grade level? We are baffled, but very relieved.

children.title: School Yard
children.description:
Parents of CP (1st grade) pupils were allowed to come on school grounds for a bit, as all those children are new to the school. We briefly got to see Milo's teacher as she made a list of who showed up for school.

We were in a room with a view of the school yard. It feels like the only time we might ever see it.

children.title: Looking Out
children.description: Dean and Milo try to spot Felix on the school yard. Felix had been in school for a little over an hour by then. The very first recess of the year was starting.

children.title: Le Nouveau
children.description: There! Here is Felix (in yellow), mobbed by curious kids who want to meet the Le Nouveau and practice their English with him.

children.title: Buddy
children.description: See the kid with the grey and black striped sweater? We don't know his name but he and Felix have become friends. Even though Felix has moved to a different class now, they have continued to meet at recess.

children.title: La Cour
children.description:
Can you spot Felix and his new friend?

Both Felix and Milo are underwhelmed by the school yard. It's just concrete and few trees. They miss EB's cool playground.

children.title: Milo's Class
children.description:
Milo and his class, les CP-B, about to be led off to their classroom in the bowels of the school. Will we ever see his room?

His teacher's name is Marie. She seems nice.

children.title: School Supplies
children.description: After school, we braved the mob of mothers at the local Carrefour supermarket and bought every item on the very detailed school supply lists (Les Fournitures Scolaires).

children.title: Supplies 2
children.description:
Let's see... 4 blue pens, 2 green pens, 2 red pens... how many glue sticks did Milo need? Felix, is that your ardoise (whiteboard)?

Don't forget to cover the cahiers (notebooks) in the correct color plastic and mark everything with your child's name.

children.title: Correspondance
children.description: Every school child in France has a "Cahier de Correspondance" (Correspondence Notebook). This is the way for teachers and parents to communicate. This is handy, since it seems the parents never get to see the teacher face to face.

children.title: Grève
children.description:
The very first message from Felix's teacher in his cahier de correspondance: "En raison d'un mouvement de grève, votre enfant n'aura pas de classe mardi 7 septembre." (Because of a strike, your child will not have school on September 7th.)

It's so delightfully French! School's barely started and already the teachers are striking. The strike is in response to President Sarkozy proposing an older retirement age for all workers.

We'd plan a big outing with the kids that day, but of course the metro and train operators are striking too.

children.title: Metro
children.description: Saturday on the Metro. Take a look at the drawings on his cast: a schtroumpf (smurf) from Lucie, a big heart from Dean, and a small "Felix ♥ Milo" from Felix.

children.title: Le Marais
children.description: We spent the afternoon strolling in the Marais district. This was in front of Le Musée de la Poupée (The Doll Museum).

children.title: Le Marais 2
children.description:
We did NOT join the throngs of girls inside The Doll Museum. Instead, we took our Y chromosomes to Le Musée de la Chasse et de la Nature (The Hunting and Nature Museum).

It had a remarkable collection of ornate hunting weapons, stuffed animals and bizarre objects including unicorn horns.

children.title: Nicolas Flamel
children.description: Dean in front of the house of Nicolas Flamel, the famous alchemist (as seen in Harry Potter). It's the oldest house in Paris.

children.title: Cafe
children.description:
We like stopping at cafes. The adults usually have a Perrier. The kids usually have sirop de fraise (water flavored with strawberry syrup).

Here, we complemented the experience with pains au chocolat from the nearest bakery.

children.title: Roquefort
children.description: You don't see any Roquefort cheese delivery truck in the U.S.

children.title: Pond
children.description: We found the pond of Le Marais (Le Marais means "the swamp"). Looks like the kids have ran out of steam for the day. Where to tomorrow?

children.title: Versailles
children.description: Versailles! The château, the gardens and the fountains are just as grandiose as you have heard. Louis XIV was The Man, no doubt about it.

children.title: Lucie
children.description: Lucie in Versailles.

children.title: Grandes Eaux
children.description: We enjoyed the choreographed fountain jets with background musical music. It's called Les Grandes Eaux Musicales de Versailles.

children.title: Titan
children.description: One of our favorites: the titan Enceladus crushed by stones and barfing a huge jet of water.

children.title: Galerie des Glaces
children.description:
Admiring the ceiling paintings in La Galerie des Glaces (the Hall of Mirrors).

Ol' Louis XIV had style out the wazoo, that's for sure.
